Question_1.Context: The study focuses on the application of a new mesh handling strategy for the simulation of gearboxes. The methodology aims to reduce computational effort and enhance efficiency in analyzing complex gear configurations.
Question_1.Question: What is the main purpose of the new mesh handling strategy implemented in the study?
Question_1.A: To increase the computational complexity of gear simulations.
Question_1.B: To introduce a more time-consuming process for mesh generation.
Question_1.C: To reduce the computational effort required for simulating complex gearboxes.
Question_1.D: To limit the flexibility in analyzing different gear configurations.
Question_1.Source: The algorithm was validated with spur, helical, and spiral bevel gearboxes demonstrating its feasibility for different gears’ type and its accuracy in the power losses trend prediction (maximum 20% error with respect to experimental data). In this framework, this development is even more significant for real industrial multi-stage gearboxes, where the current available finite volume methods would suffer from severe computational costs.

Question_2.Context: The study discusses the advantages of using the opensource software OpenFOAM® for implementing the new mesh handling strategy for gear simulations.
Question_2.Question: Why was OpenFOAM® chosen for implementing the new mesh handling strategy?
Question_2.A: Due to its high cost compared to other software options.
Question_2.B: For its limited flexibility and customization capabilities.
Question_2.C: Because of its open-source nature and flexibility for customization.
Question_2.D: Because it requires additional licenses for parallel computing.
Question_2.Source: The approach is completely general; it can be implemented in each programming language and coupled transversally with any CFD solver. The specific choice of implementing this algorithm within OpenFOAM® is related to its simplicity: OpenFOAM® is open-source and already written in C++ which promotes a complete integration with the actual code.
